name: Antwerp
fun_fact: Fun fact: Antwerp's legendary herbal liqueur, Elixir d'Anvers (invented in 1863), was once given to Babar the elephant at Antwerp Zoo when he was sickâ€”and after three bottles, he recovered! The 160-year-old recipe of 32 herbs and spices remains a family secret, and the liqueur was even recommended for 'apathetic women, stressed-out men, and sluggish horses.'

hero_dishes.name: Stoofvlees (Vlaamse Karbonaden)
hero_dishes.description: Dark, beer-braised beef stew slow-cooked with local brown ale, onions, mustard, and a slice of bread to thicken the sauce. Deep flavor, tender meat, served with golden fries and mayo.
hero_dishes.origin_story: A staple across Belgian tables for generations, this hearty stew reflects Belgium's love for beer-based cooking and rich, slow-simmered comfort food.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: De Groote Witte Arend (Reyndersstraat), Elfde Gebod, or De Arme Duivel for authentic stoofvlees with character

hero_dishes.name: Paling in 't Groen (Eel in Green Sauce)
hero_dishes.description: Freshwater eel cooked in a bright green herb sauce made with sorrel, parsley, watercress, and chervil. Bold, earthy, and uniquely Flemish.
hero_dishes.origin_story: A traditional Flemish specialty that locals love and tourists sometimes fearâ€”until they taste the vibrant herbal sauce and tender eel. Often served with fries or bread to soak up every drop.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional Flemish restaurants throughout Antwerp's historic center

hero_dishes.name: Antwerpse Handjes
hero_dishes.description: Antwerp's signature 'hands' cookies or chocolates filled with marzipan and Elixir d'Anvers. Made from sanddough with almonds (biscuit version) or milk chocolate.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Named after the city's legend of the giant Druon Antigoon, whose severed hand was thrown into the River Scheldt. 'Antwerpen' means 'hand throwing' in Dutch, and these hand-shaped treats are the city's most iconic edible souvenir.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Bakeries and chocolate shops throughout the city center, especially near Grote Markt

hero_dishes.name: Moules-Frites
hero_dishes.description: North Sea mussels steamed in white wine, garlic, and celery, served with crispy twice-fried Belgian frites and mayo. Eaten by hand.
hero_dishes.origin_story: While common throughout Belgium, Antwerp's harborside location means unbeatable freshness. Peak season runs from July through February.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Harborside restaurants and traditional brasseries. Restaurant Octave (near Central Station) offers creative Belgian takes on classics

signature_drinks.name: Bolleke (De Koninck Beer)
signature_drinks.description: Antwerp's beloved local beerâ€”a 5% ABV amber ale served in distinctive half-spherical glasses called 'bollekes'
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Locals meet at historic bars like Quinten Matsijs (one of the oldest bars in Antwerp) to drink Bolleke from its iconic rounded glass. The beer has been brewed in Antwerp since 1833 and is deeply intertwined with the city's identity.

signature_drinks.name: Elixir d'Anvers
signature_drinks.description: A golden-yellow herbal liqueur made from 32 plants and herbs including cinnamon, saffron, and star anise. Invented in 1863 by pharmacist FranÃ§ois-Xavier De Beukelaer, the exact recipe remains a family secret for five generations.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Traditionally served as a digestif or added to coffee. Historically given to children on sugar cubes, fed to sick horses, and recommended for 'apathetic women and stressed-out men.' Still fills the marzipan center of Antwerpse Handjes cookies.

signature_drinks.name: Belgian Frites with Sauces
signature_drinks.description: Thick-cut fries fried twice for perfect crispiness, served in paper cones with creative sauces like truffle mayo and basil remoulade
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: In the 17th century, polluted waterways meant drinking beer (rather than unclean water) was the only safe option. A water pipe ran directly to brewers' street to supply clean water to breweries. This made Antwerp a beer-drinking city by necessity, now by culture. Frites are the perfect beer companion.

food_culture_notes: Antwerp boasts one of the world's highest number of pubs per capita
In 2016, UNESCO inscribed Belgian beer culture on their list of intangible cultural heritage of humanity
Belgians now drink 68 liters of beer each year, down from around 200 in 1900
Almost every Belgian beer has its own uniquely shaped, branded glass
The historic Seefhoek district was named after an ancient local buckwheat brew called Seef
Brewing in Antwerp dates back to the 1300sâ€”there used to be hundreds of breweries, now just a few remain
Beer Passion weekend (July) and Modeste Bier Festival (October) celebrate Antwerp's brewing heritage
The diamond district contrasts with the city's earthy, beer-soaked culinary traditions
